user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of send_bad_request:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
send_bad_request (struct MHD_Connection *con)
{
  struct MHD_Response *res;
  enum MHD_Result ret;

  res =
    MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static (strlen (BAD_REQUEST_PAGE),
                                            (const void *) BAD_REQUEST_PAGE);
  ret = MHD_queue_response (con, MHD_HTTP_BAD_REQUEST, res);
  MHD_destroy_response (res);
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function send_bad_request:
#define BAD_REQUEST_PAGE "<html>\n""<head>\n""<title>WebSocket chat</title>\n""</head>\n""<body>\n""Bad Request\n""</body>\n""</html>\n"
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
#define BAD_REQUEST_PAGE "<html>\n""<head>\n""<title>WebSocket chat</title>\n""</head>\n""<body>\n""Bad Request\n""</body>\n""</html>\n"
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation in the shown fragment. BAD_REQUEST_PAGE is a string literal and in the provided function it is passed as (const void *)BAD_REQUEST_PAGE, so the pointer is const-qualified. A concrete violation would be assigning the literal to a non-const pointer or passing it to a function parameter typed as a non-const pointer (e.g. char *p = BAD_REQUEST_PAGE; or calling a function expecting char * without const), which would breach Rule 8.13.
